channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2025 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2025 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: I could not have become an astronomer on my own
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02222-5

An astronomy conference changed the course of Brenda Namumba’s career and taught her the importance of networks.
item.dc:title: I could not have become an astronomer on my own
item.dc:creator: Sarah Wild

item.title: India to penalize universities with too many retractions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02364-6

Having a lot of withdrawn papers will soon count against institutions but some warn the policy could create issues.
item.dc:title: India to penalize universities with too many retractions
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty

item.title: ‘Congress has your back’: US senators tell scientists they want to protect NIH budget
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02448-3

Senate budget bill includes small increase for the health-research agency — but faces a long road before being signed into law.
item.dc:title: ‘Congress has your back’: US senators tell scientists they want to protect NIH budget
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Intricate origins of ice mummy’s ink revealed
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02327-x

Imaging suggests that more than one tattooist applied pigment to the hands and forearms of a woman who lived more than two millennia ago.
item.dc:title: Intricate origins of ice mummy’s ink revealed

item.title: My AI chatbot thinks my idea is fundable
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02190-w

A dialogue with artificial intelligence has changed how Angela Steinauer thinks through her ideas. The trick is staying sceptical and asking better questions.
item.dc:title: My AI chatbot thinks my idea is fundable
item.dc:creator: Angela Steinauer

item.title: Google AI model mines trillions of images to create maps of Earth ‘at any place and time’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02412-1

The system will save time spent on processing satellite data, researchers say — but they hope the tech firm will share more about how it works.
item.dc:title: Google AI model mines trillions of images to create maps of Earth ‘at any place and time’
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: Lava planets’ atmospheres give away what lies beneath
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02328-w

Modelling suggests that data collected by JWST will be able to distinguish between planets that are molten to the core and those that are not.
item.dc:title: Lava planets’ atmospheres give away what lies beneath

item.title: Transient APC/C inactivation by mTOR boosts glycolysis during cell cycle entry
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 July 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09328-w

APC/C activity is transiently inhibited to generate a pulse of glycolysis that is required for mammalian cell cycle entry.
item.dc:title: Transient APC/C inactivation by mTOR boosts glycolysis during cell cycle entry

item.title: Towards more effective nature-based climate solutions in global forests
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 July 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09116-6

A strategy to improve the implementation of nature-based climate solutions in global forests for climate mitigation is described, comprising four key components to highlight notable science and policy considerations and providing solutions to improve rigour.
item.dc:title: Towards more effective nature-based climate solutions in global forests

item.title: SuFEx-based antitubercular compound irreversibly inhibits Pks13
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 July 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09286-3

A preclinical covalent compound, CMX410, contains a aryl fluorosulfate warhead that targets the acyltransferase domain of Mtb Pks13, an essential enzyme in cell-wall biosynthesis, making it a promising candidate for tuberculosis treatment regimens.
item.dc:title: SuFEx-based antitubercular compound irreversibly inhibits Pks13

item.title: SMART tool builds proteins on cell surfaces
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02411-2

Researchers can target effector proteins to cells on the basis of which molecules those cells express.
item.dc:title: SMART tool builds proteins on cell surfaces
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Daily briefing: What does quantum mechanics mean anyway?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02444-7

A Nature survey reveals that physicists disagree on even the basics of what quantum mechanics means in reality. Plus, sugars on a cell’s surface mapped at unprecedented resolution and the world’s wildest biology conference.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: What does quantum mechanics mean anyway?
item.dc:creator: Jacob Smith

item.title: Laser beams programmed to form various shapes by nanodisk arrays
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02383-3

‘Metalasers’ have been developed using metasurfaces comprising nanodisks, each with an off-centre hole. By changing the rotation angle of the nanodisks’ holes, the wavefront of the metalaser’s emission can be modified to generate arbitrarily shaped beam profiles, including focal spots, vortices and holograms, with notably low levels of ‘speckle’ noise.
item.dc:title: Laser beams programmed to form various shapes by nanodisk arrays

item.title: The tiny mouse lemur could make for a mighty model organism
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-01584-0

A cellular atlas for a small, fast-reproducing primate could set the stage for scientists to use it as a model organism that has more human relevance than rodents.
item.dc:title: The tiny mouse lemur could make for a mighty model organism
item.dc:creator: J. Gray Camp

item.title: Scientific bedlam at the world’s weirdest and wildest research conference
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02169-7

Woodstock Bio2 + Night Science aimed to encourage collaborations through creativity. The walk-on music for presentations was fun, too.
item.dc:title: Scientific bedlam at the world’s weirdest and wildest research conference
item.dc:creator: Josie Glausiusz

item.title: Observation of elusive interaction between neutrinos and atomic nuclei
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02134-4

Neutrinos are particles that are notoriously hard to detect, but observations of a process called coherent elastic neutrino–nucleus scattering could enable physicists to develop better ways of studying them.
item.dc:title: Observation of elusive interaction between neutrinos and atomic nuclei
item.dc:creator: Henry T. Wong

item.title: Physicists should revel in the diversity of ways to understand quantum mechanics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02346-8

Nature survey shows that disagreement about the meaning of quantum physics remains strong, even 100 years in. And that’s OK.
item.dc:title: Physicists should revel in the diversity of ways to understand quantum mechanics

item.title: From bench to big boss: mitigating the widening gap between PI and lab
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-01912-4

Laboratory dynamics can change as the age and experience of the principal investigator increase. But there are ways to combat this.
item.dc:title: From bench to big boss: mitigating the widening gap between PI and lab
item.dc:creator: Matthias Rillig
Henning Sprekeler

item.title: Physicists disagree wildly on what quantum mechanics says about reality, Nature survey shows
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02342-y

First major attempt to chart researchers’ views finds interpretations in conflict.
item.dc:title: Physicists disagree wildly on what quantum mechanics says about reality, Nature survey shows
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: Sleuths and scientific institutions are not rivals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02347-7

Science detectives are helping the research community to hold itself to account. All involved must find better ways to work together.
item.dc:title: Sleuths and scientific institutions are not rivals

item.title: Can science address painters’ problems?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02139-z

Wall decorators and artists seek solutions, and insects plunge to their pitcher-plant fate, in this week’s pick from Nature’s archive.
item.dc:title: Can science address painters’ problems?

item.title: Daily briefing: The brain deploys immune cells at the mere sight of sickness
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02434-9

When we see a sick person, our brains kickstart an immune response mimicking the body’s response to an actual infection. Plus, evolution has a predilection for anteaters and how researchers are testing people, animals and artificial intelligence for consciousness.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: The brain deploys immune cells at the mere sight of sickness
item.dc:creator: Jacob Smith

item.title: How China’s bold talent recruitment has shaped science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02336-w

Many Chinese researchers have received enviable benefits and positions after returning from training abroad.
item.dc:title: How China’s bold talent recruitment has shaped science
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty

item.title: Scientists mourn Tom Lehrer — nerdiest of singer-songwriters
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02417-w

The mathematician’s memorable satires are beloved by generations of researchers.
item.dc:title: Scientists mourn Tom Lehrer — nerdiest of singer-songwriters
item.dc:creator: Philip Ball

item.title: AI models are neglecting African languages — scientists want to change that
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02292-5

Scientists record 9,000 hours of languages spoken in Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa as free-access training data for AI models.
item.dc:title: AI models are neglecting African languages — scientists want to change that
item.dc:creator: Sarah Wild

item.title: How to detect consciousness in people, animals and maybe even AI
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02349-5

Insights from human brains could inform how scientists search for awareness in all its possible forms.
item.dc:title: How to detect consciousness in people, animals and maybe even AI
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Columbia researchers eager to restart science after university’s deal with Trump
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02403-2

The institution agreed to increased federal oversight in exchange for restored grants and an end to government investigations.
item.dc:title: Columbia researchers eager to restart science after university’s deal with Trump
item.dc:creator: Jenna Ahart
Alexandra Witze

item.title: Could bridging science and the arts be the key to better policies?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02351-x

To be successful, policymakers need to consider diverse perspectives. Here’s how we’re reimagining policy process.
item.dc:title: Could bridging science and the arts be the key to better policies?
item.dc:creator: Caterina Benincasa
Adriaan Eeckels

item.title: Hard paths: how courage differs from bravery in science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-01861-y

‘If it’s easy, someone else will do it.’ Leah Ellis, chief executive of Sublime Systems, explains the challenge and appeal of slashing carbon emissions from cement production.
item.dc:title: Hard paths: how courage differs from bravery in science
item.dc:creator: Emma Ulker

item.title: Physicists unleashed the power of the atom — but to what end?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02350-y

From laboratory quirks to Earth-shattering weapons, a chain of discoveries reached a devastating conclusion.
item.dc:title: Physicists unleashed the power of the atom — but to what end?
item.dc:creator: Ann Finkbeiner
